titleStmt.title: Aratea Digital
Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, MS latin 8663

editionStmt.edition: Digital edition according to TEI P5

availability.licence: This document is published under the Creative Commons licence Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY 4.0).

msDesc.head:
Astronomical compilation Fleury (?), Tours (?) s. X-XI1
Digital facsimile at gallica.bnf.fr

supportDesc.foliation: In pencil and ink in the upper right corner of every folium.

collation.p: Composed, according to Moster, from three homogeneous and contemporary parts: ff. 1-24, ff. 25-46 and ff. 47-58 (Mostert's BF 1155, 1156 and 1157 accordingly).

supportDesc.condition: The manuscript lost at least two quaternions between ff. 32 and 33. See note to25r-44v.

history.origin: All three parts show palaeographical similarities and where probably written in the Loire valley ins. X-XI1 , scholars suggesting Fleury (Carey) and Tours (Saxl) as possible place of production.
history.provenance: The verse on f.58v suggests the manuscript was in Fleury in the s. XI.
In thes. XVII it belonged to the Philibert de La Mare.

listBibl.head: Selected Bibliography:
listBibl.bibl: Bernhard, Michael, ed.Anonymi saeculi decimi vel undecimi tractatus de musica “Dulce ingenium musicae”. Veröffentlichungen der Musikhistorischen Kommission 6. München, 1987, esp. pp. 5-6.
Carey, Frederick.De Scriptura Floriacensi. Unpublished diss. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University, 1923.

Vernet, Marie-Thérèse. “Notes de Dom André Wilmart † sur quelques manuscrits latins anciens de la Bibliothèque nationale de Paris.”Bulletin d’information de l’Institut de Recherche et d’Histoire des Textes, no. 8 (1960): 7–46, esp. pp. 40-44.
Barker-Benfield, R.C. "A ninth-century manuscript from Fleury." InMedieval Learning and Literature. Oxford, 1976, pp. 145-165, here p. 155.

msItem.author: Hyginus
msItem.title: De astronomia
msItem.incipit: Et si te studio gramaticae artis inductum non solum uersuum moderatione
msItem.explicit: annum uoluerunt esse cum sol a haestiuo circulore dieris CCCos LXVI dies suo cursu transigit.
msItem.decoNote: Large decorated initial E on f. 1r; drawing of Centaurus on f. 11v inside the text.

msItem.title: De ordine ac positione
msItem.rubric: De ordine ac positione stellarum in signis
msItem.incipit: Est quidem hic ordo ac positio siderum quae fixa caelo

msItem.title: De positione et cursu septem planetarum
msItem.rubric: De positione et cursu septem planetarum
msItem.incipit: Inter caelum et terram certis discreta spatiis VII sydera pendent
msItem.explicit: Dein morata in coitu solis biduo cum tardissime a tricesima luce ad easdem uices exit.
msItem.decoNote: Drawings of the planets as human bust scluptures with their names written in a halo around their heads. Drawing of the Sun missing (only a headingSol).

msItem.title: De absidibus earum
msItem.incipit: Tres sunt autem quas supras solem diximus sitas
msItem.explicit: sicut in rotis radios ut subiecta figura demonstrat.

msItem.author: Macrobius
msItem.title: Commentarium in somnium Scipionis
msItem.rubric: Macrobii Ambrosii Theodosii v. c. et in l. commenta ex cicerone in somnium scipionis.
msItem.incipit: Inter platonis et ciceronis libros quos de republica uterque constituit
msItem.finalRubric: Macrobii Ambrosii commenta ex cicerone in somnium scipionis explicit.
msItem.note: Lacuna of probably two quaternions between ff. 32 and 33. On f. 32v the text ends in mid lib. 1, cap. 11id est inferos uocauerunt and f. 33r begins with mid lib. 1, cap. 21 referens quo a ueteribus et temptata est.
msItem.decoNote: Decorated zoomorphic initials on f.25r and 34v (begin of Book 2); f. 34r rain diagram; f. 35v Lambda diagram; ff. 37v and 38v diagram of the celestial and terrestrial circles; f. 39v diagram of the terrestrial globe.

msItem.author: Cicero
msItem.title: Somnium Scipionis
msItem.note: On f. 44v introductory note:Incipit somnium scipionis quod macrobius exponens adeuste dominum filium suum duos edidit libros in quibus subtiliter disseruit de bono senectutis et de natura animae uiciisque eius et uirtutibus de diuersitatibus etiam et nominibus somniorum necnon et de natura numerorum et diuisione de sideribus quoque et stellis de numero et magnitudine caelestium circulorum de positione ac magnitudine celi ac terrae de magnitudine et defectu necnon et cursu soli et lunae de VII planetis et de armonia caeli.
msItem.rubric: Somnium scipionis M. Tullii Ciceronis excerptum ex libro VI de re publica.
msItem.incipit: Cum in africam uenissem A manlio consule
msItem.explicit: qui nec pauciores et certe meliores fuere uiri
msItem.note: Two thirds of the page left blank.
blank, marks from drawing of circles perhaps later additions for the following text of Gerbert.

msItem.author: Gerbert of Aurillac
msItem.title: Letter to Constantine of Fleury on the abacus
msItem.incipit: Uis amiciciae penae impossibilia redigit ad possibilia. Nam quomodo rationes numerorm abaci explicare contenderemus nisite ad ortante omni dulce solamen laborum

listBibl.bibl: Gerbert of Aurillac.The Letters of Gerbert with His Papal Privileges as Sylvester II. Translated by Harriet Pratt Lattin. New York: Columbia Univ. Press, 1961.

msItem.note: The letter is followed by Regulae multiplicationis and Regulae divisionis
msItem.incipit: Si multiplicaueris singularem numerum per X dabis unicuique digiti X et omni articulo C

msItem.author: Herigerus Lobiensis
msItem.title: Regulae de numerorum abaci rationibus
msItem.incipit: Singularem per decenum si multiplicaueris dabis digitos X articulos C
msItem.explicit: Hic ulterius ad hanc consequentiam multiplicantur numeri etiamsi interminabilis multitudinis fiat abacus.
sic diuisores per denominutionem totius dividendi multiplicabuntur.

msItem.title: Regulae de numerorum abaci rationibus
msItem.incipit: Quomodo decenus metitur centenum aut millenum vel millenus ulteriores. Si volueris per decenum numerum dividere

msItem.author: Gerbertus of Aurillac
msItem.title: Epistola ad fratrem Adam
msItem.incipit: Marcianus in astrologia incrementa horarum ita fieri putat
msItem.decoNote: two tables illustrating the lenght of day and night with headings Horologium secundum eos qui diem maximum habent horarum aequinoctialium XVIII and Item horologium hellesponti ubi dies maximum est horarum XV.

msItem.note: Anonymous work on the measure of monocords
msItem.incipit: Dulce ingenium musicae quamuis instrumentis plurimis uigeat
msItem.explicit: huius tropi talis est forma NOEAGIS.
msItem.note: On f. 51r a tonarium; according to Vernet it is executed in the style of the Loire area.
msItem.bibl: Bernhard, Michael.Anonymi saeculi decimi vel undecimi tractatus de musica 'Dulce ingenium musicae'. Munich, 1987.

msItem.title: Apuleian Sphere
msItem.incipit: Sphera apulegii de egris uel monomachis, si uis scire qua die decumbant uel liberentur
msItem.explicit: si infra mortem uel casum monomachi monstrabit.
msItem.decoNote: Diagram of the sphere with headings int he middleVita Mors.

msItem.note: Text on measures (later addition in two column).
On the inner margin added as a third column a table of measures.

msItem.incipit: Congregati sunt deus ad deuorandum me
msItem.explicit: deus meus in adiutorium meum intende.

msItem.quote: Delicta iuuentutis mee ne memineris domine et ne auersas faciem tuam a me quoniam tribulor uelociter exaudime domine.
Reminiscere misericordie tue domine et ap peccatis absolue quos regenerasti baptismatis in fonte.
Miserere ihesu christe miserere qui umbrosum inluminasti infernum da eis splendidissimum lumen ut possuit uidere perpetuam lucem.
Deus meus ne elongeris. alia deus meus in auxilium. alia deus meus inadiutorium.
Redemptor meus uiuit et in nouissimo resurgam et renouabuntur denuo ossa mea in carne mea uidebo dominum meum.
Lauda anima mea dominum laudabo dominum in uita mea psallam deo meo quandiu ero.

msItem.note: with interlinear notation and traces of French, Lotharingian and Aquitanian neumes (Mostert).
msItem.bibl: Hesbert, Dom R.-J. “L’office de la commémoraison des dédunts à Saint-Benoît-sur-Loire au XIIIe siècle.” InMiscellanea liturgica in honorem L. Cuniberti Mohlberg, 2:393–421. Rome: Edizioni Liturgiche, 1949.

msItem.note:
Later additions and verses:Florida floriacum perlustrauit pragmata claustri
floret florigerum dogmatis hic studium.
